text: How can we write multiple dispatch functions which takes the arguments in either order without writing the function twice?

elements.text: How can we write multiple dispatch functions which takes the arguments in either order without writing the function twice?

foo(a::T, b::U) = ...
foo(b::U, a::T) = foo(a, b)

text: But I would suggest making an effort to keep the calling convention of your function as consistent as possible throughout your code, i.e. choose one canonical order and coerce the arguments to fit, rather than the function.

elements.text: But I would suggest making an effort to keep the calling convention of your function as consistent as possible throughout your code, i.e. choose one canonical order and coerce the arguments to fit, rather than the function.

text:
Thank you boston <@U019K6Q9N15>
Is keeping the arguments consistent related to performance or readability?

elements.text: Is keeping the arguments consistent related to performance or readability?

text: more of consistency, and stability of thinking process. if you are consistent, no guessing game unless you want to indicate commutative property. besides, if you want to support any order argument, it will be factorial to cover all permutations. for 3 arguments, there are 6 possible arrangement. if user expect any arrangement, you will have to define this 6 possible ways.

text: What do you want this for? Alternatives are using keyword arguments or, if applicable, define the many arguments function as a reduction of the 2 arguments one (it is done for eg. `+`).
